323255758.reviewBody: This aqueduct is located between a beautiful park and the Quinta Real Hotel. It is well preserved and will serve as a lovely backdrop for phots.

314457556.name: A must see at night.
314457556.author: a TripAdvisor user
314457556.reviewBody: While this has been maintained, and repaired due to its age its amazing to think this was made just so the town could have water.\nWe stay at the Quinta Real, which is at the base of this and the night view is nothing short of amazing.

305332656.name: Worth a visit
305332656.author: a TripAdvisor user
305332656.reviewBody: Well preserved aqueduct in a pleasant part of town. Worth combining with the museum de Francisco Goitia and the old bull ring (now part of a 5 star hotel close to the aqueduct)

262718836.name: Historic aqueduct .... a great entry point and reference when entering and exiting historical Zacatecas!
262718836.author: a TripAdvisor user
262718836.reviewBody: Historic aqueduct .... a great entry point and reference when entering and exiting historical Zacatecas!

260810316.name: Historic landmark
260810316.author: a TripAdvisor user
260810316.reviewBody: This is similar to the aqueduct found in Morelia and has the same historic interest.  it is worth seeing.

253093553.name: Beautiful Park
253093553.author: a TripAdvisor user
253093553.reviewBody: This has to be part of your walking tour. The colonial architecture is impressive and it is accompanied by a lovely, peaceful park. Nearby is a lovely church that is worth the walk up the hill to view.

240886750.name: Follow it to the end for the pot of gold
240886750.author: a TripAdvisor user
240886750.reviewBody: The aqueduct is cool considering it was the source of water for the city and it is still standing.  If you start at the north end, follow it all the way down to the south end where it will intersect with the Quita Real hotel, the site of the first bull ring in Mexico.  It is really an amazing construction and you can go right down onto the bull ring floor to get the full experience.  I would also suggest having a cup of coffee in the hotel cafe and enjoying the view while you are there.

236194926.name: Water
236194926.author: a TripAdvisor user
236194926.reviewBody: It seems as each of the central mountain silver towns has its own aqueduct, emphasizing the dryness of the land and the ingenuity of the settlers. This is the only one I recall seeing with buttresses.

194960007.name: Portion of the aqueduct still standing
194960007.author: a TripAdvisor user
194960007.reviewBody: Only a short portion of the aqueduct still stands, but because of its historical value, it is very well maintained, and is a terrific photo op.

178757898.name: Worth a Look
178757898.author: a TripAdvisor user
178757898.reviewBody: It is very well preserved (restored I believe).  Beautiful stone work.  While here - visit the former bull fighting ring nearby (now a hotel and restaurant but also worth seeing!)

153405005.name: Wonderful Landmark
153405005.author: a TripAdvisor user
153405005.reviewBody: The Aqueduct is one of the best preserved Aqueducts that I\'ve seen in Mexico. Amazing to think that these graceful arches once brought water to the town.  A good landmark as you travel around Zacatacas.

599371967.name: Beautiful space
599371967.author: a TripAdvisor user
599371967.reviewBody: In front of the Pedro Coronel museum, sunny plaza with a view of the top of the Basilica.\nGood place to rest.

579332489.name: Great plaza
579332489.author: a TripAdvisor user
579332489.reviewBody: If you visit teh Pedro Coronel Museum in the old jesuit convent or the church of Santo Domingo, you will find yourself in this lovely square. It is obviously useful to combine the visit with these two monuments and it is only one minute walk from the Cathedral.

577702923.name: Must see
577702923.author: a TripAdvisor user
577702923.reviewBody: As with all the churches in Zacatecas, you must visit them, and not only on the outside, some are worth your wile inside too.

501273277.name: Amazing historic site
501273277.author: a TripAdvisor user
501273277.reviewBody: Truly beautiful and unique.  This entire city is so clean, well kept, people were all so gracious and warm.  I think we stopped and sat around this area every day for a week just because it was so beautiful.

433193916.name: Don\'t miss
433193916.author: a TripAdvisor user
433193916.reviewBody: Very beautiful place, very central. Lovely construction of church, near many other places of interest. You will enjoy it.

429251444.name: beautiful
429251444.author: a TripAdvisor user
429251444.reviewBody: the museum and the church are good sights, you can just stop by when you are walking around the area.

399111616.name: Zacatecas is great
399111616.author: a TripAdvisor user
399111616.reviewBody: Not only the square, the whole city center is great. Walk around, loose yourself, taste son local food. Look into shops an markets.\nPeople are friendly. Houses are stunning.\nSo much to see and discover ...

390558347.name: Beautiful place
390558347.author: a TripAdvisor user
390558347.reviewBody: This is one of the places I like the most in Zacatecas. It\u00b4s gorgeous! Beautiful architecture, quite surroundings and near to the cathedral and the Coronel museum.

292920619.name: Small plaza
292920619.author: a TripAdvisor user
292920619.reviewBody: This plaza is nothing special, but it is the home of Iglesia de Santo Domingo and Museo de Pedro Coronel.\n\nThe plaza is very small and very few people actually spend any time at the plaza except for visit the church or the museum.

262717250.name: Primary plaza in a very historical city in Mexico!
262717250.author: a TripAdvisor user
262717250.reviewBody: Primary plaza in a very historical city in Mexico! This plaza sometimes has bands and a lot of people hanging out at nighttime ... interesting to imagine all of the history that occurred here!

241867078.name: Plaza?
241867078.author: a TripAdvisor user
241867078.reviewBody: They call this a plaza but it\'s so small it should be called a plazetta. Used more as a walkway than as a meeting place.

178757254.name: Don\'t Blink...
178757254.author: a TripAdvisor user
178757254.reviewBody: We almost missed this plaza - but when we did recognize where we were, we spent a little time - beautiful, and you can get a few nice shots.

146459160.name: Almost missed it
146459160.author: a TripAdvisor user
146459160.reviewBody: This plaza is very small so you might pass it and not know it. I saw very few people here, as most people hang around Plaza de Armas. We continued on our walking tour zig zagging through all the city streets.

623816178.name: Newly Opened Archaeological Site is Marvellous
623816178.author: a TripAdvisor user
623816178.reviewBody:
The city of Teúl de González Ortega is located in the southern part of the state of Zacatecas, 100 kilometers north of Guadalajara. Teúl is one of Mexico’s Pueblos Mágicos, or Magic Cities and well deserves the name. I found the houses pretty, the streets clean and well paved, and there seemed to be picturesque arches everywhere. It can also be said that everywhere you wander in this town, you can always see the Cerro de Teúl on the horizon, so stately and imposing that even the notorious Conquistador Nuño Beltrán de Guzmán, remarked upon its grandeur.

On October 5, 2018, the archaeological site on the Cerro was inaugurated, and it seemed the whole town turned out for the event. There was standing room only as politician after politician alluded to the deep love of the local people for this mountain of theirs and to the wholehearted support the archaeologists had received for their project. “My friends,” archaeologist Laura Soler told the crowd, “We are finally finished doing our work and we will no longer keep you away from your beloved peñol. From now on it will be open to the public every day of the week but Monday.”

I learned that excavations and studies had been carried out by Soler and archaeologist Peter Jiménez for ten long years and that this particular site is considered of monumental importance because it was occupied continuously for 17 to 19 centuries, so its history matches and reflects the history of northwestern Mexico.

A very wide, smooth, well-marked trail leads from the town up the mountainside, with stairs built in a few strategic places and occasional shaded spots with benches where you can catch your breath and take a rest. The most dramatic “rest stop” is a very long shelter cave with seats carved into the living rock by ancient peoples. Here you can sit in the shade and enjoy a magnificent, panoramic view of Teul de González. Also carved into the rock wall are horizontal and vertical channels for collecting the spring water which oozes out of this mountain at various points.

It’s good that there are plenty of places to rest along the trail, because this is one steep hill, with a vertical difference of 171 meters between the town and the shaft tomb up at the very top, but it’s only a one-kilometer walk through spectacular scenery. Scattered along the way are well-designed explanatory signs (sorry, entirely in Spanish), each of which is linked to an app called “Explora Cerro del Teùl” which you can download free from the Google Play Store. The app uses GPS to recognize where you are and presents lots of info, cartoon style. People were oohing and ahhing about this ultramodern guide, but as for me, I’d still rather read a sign than squint at a tiny screen obviously not designed for bright sunlight.

Up, up you go and suddenly you reach a wide, flat area with a plaza, the ruins of a pyramid and a sunken patio where great crowds used to gather for “Mitote Ceremonies,” dances held, for example, in May to assure the arrival of the rains and in October or November asking the gods to end them. Here the archaeologists found many fragments of simple ceramics that had been used to prepare food for these big crowds. 

Something else the archaeologists found buried beneath this patio, I was surprised to learn, were around 60 skeletons, probably the remains of ancient VIPs. “These people,” Laura Soler told us, “typically had artificially flattened heads and their teeth had been filed to sharp points.  All these skeletons have been sent off for study by bioarchaeologists, but there are probably many more bodies under here that we haven’t uncovered yet, just a few centimeters beneath your feet.”

A few steps from the patio we came to the I-shaped ball court, which is very nicely preserved. There, our guide showed us two of four big statues carved in stone, which had once stood at the four extremities of the ball court. “These figures,” said Soler, “are shown dressed in the typical sportswear and gloves of the day.”

Most curious of all was the fact that one of the four statues found here had been deliberately sculpted in two parts: a body and a head, apparently in relation to the preHispanic custom of honoring the captain of the winning team with decapitation.

A few steps up above the ball court, you come to the last feature of the archaeological tour: a shaft tomb, clearly indicating how far back the Cerro del Teúl goes. This method of burial was in vogue 2000 years ago, but probably died out around 400 AD. The pit or shaft could be as deep as 20 meters, with several chambers at the bottom, each containing at least one body accompanied by many ofrendas, offerings…perhaps in the thousands. To protect the tomb from looting, the shaft would typically be filled back in with dirt.

Back down at the Visitors Center, who did I bump into but Peter Jiménez, with whom I had previously corresponded—all in Spanish—without ever realizing he spoke English. “Actually, I’m from Rochester, Minnesota,” he told me. “I came to Mexico to study archaeology when I was 17 and I just stayed here. I’ve been doing archaeology here in Zacatecas for 34 years.”

“How long have you been involved in this project?” I asked Jiménez.

“Well, I first came here to Teúl in 1984, hoping to work on this site, but we realized that the ruins at La Quemada, further north in Zacatecas, were in dreadful condition and we’d better fix that place up before starting on a new one. At one time I had 520 people working for me at La Quemada, picking up the stones so we could put everything back together again. That site was like an old man in an emergency room, with kidney problems, liver problems and brain problems. So we had to do emergency archaeology there to save the site.”

Eventually Jiménez came back to Teúl, where he has been working for ten years. “The Cerro del Teúl is tremendously important,” he told me. “While La Quemada had only about six years of occupation, Teúl has been continuously occupied for 15 to 16 centuries, stretching from the Shaft-Tomb period to the arrival of the Spaniards. It shows us that dramatic changes did not mean people died or vanished, but simply that new ideas came along and the directionality vector changed. People started imitating lifestyles from somewhere else. Long-duration sites like this one at Teúl help us to see these changes.”

The newly opened archaeological site has a Visitors’ Center, restrooms and a First Aid Center and is open Tuesdays to Sundays from 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM. To get there, ask Google to take you to “Zona arqueologico del Teul.”

610333376.name: Strenuous but beautiful hike
610333376.author: a TripAdvisor user
610333376.reviewBody: If you like history and beautiful views, this is the hike for you. The climb to the very top of the hill is strenuous but the trail is now well maintained with frequent rest stations with benches and shade. Cerro del Te\u00fal, Cerro del Sombrero or the Caxcan hill top community of Tonaycac\u00e1n, "from where the mother watches",  is an active archaeological site with exciting discoveries being made. The site is currently the longest continuously inhabited site in Mexico and its record is reshaping our understanding of Mesoamerican cultures. The hill is an Atlpetl, a "water hill" both in the literal and metaphoric sense. Springs of water flow from one side of the hill and Atllpetl was the nahuatl name used to describe religious and cultural centers of influence in Mesoamerica. Some of the uncovered artifacts have been a sunken plaza complete with a small pyramid, a ball court with a pair of statues at one end that allude to the hero twins of the Popol Vuh. Also, undisturbed shaft tombs, a copper furnace and many other artifacts dating up to the most recent inhabitants, the Caxcan confederacy. If you look at the hill as you climb, you will see parapets. These were built to defend the hill from rival indigenous nations and lastly from Spanish invaders. Nu\u00f1o de Guzman or as he was known among his peers, "Bloody Guzman", attempted to conquer the region with violence and imposing slavery on the indigenous communities. Guzman\'s behavior was so extreme that even his Spanish soldiers were aghast. He was taken back to Spain and tried but Guzman\'s actions sparked the Mixton War, a conflict between the Spanish colonizers and their Tlaxcaltec allies and a united indigenous alliance of nations which challenged Spanish colonial power so severely that they considered abandoning the region altogether. The hill played a role as a pe\u00f1ol hill fortress where the Caxcanes and their allies resisted the Spanish for many years. After a peace was achieved, the present town of Te\u00fal was founded as a villa. A villa was a place where indigenous people were instructed by the Spanish indigenous allies into the new ways of Spanish colonial society. The very top of the hill, offers stunning views of the town and surrounding area. I recommend starting early in the morning or late in the afternoon as the sun may make it hard to climb. Bring comfortable shoes, pants (ticks are common) and plenty of water. At leisurely pace you\'ll be able to reach the top in about an hour.

599374764.name: Nice works, pretty house ...
599374764.author: a TripAdvisor user
599374764.reviewBody: ... and garden. Beautifully presented pieces with an interesting permanent collection. Goitia, a fin de siecle artist, had a very dark vision. Some interesting pieces to be sure.

509463226.reviewBody: This museum was an old mansion that has since been converted into a museum. There were some of the most morbid works of art I\'ve seen but beautiful nonetheless!!

address.streetAddress: Enrique Estrada 102 Col. Sierra de Alica

455493109.name: Surprising collection
455493109.author: a TripAdvisor user
455493109.reviewBody:
I'm not sure how to rate this museum as art preferences are so subjective, but given the art collection, the historic building, and the garden setting, I think it's a 3.5 - 4.

The Goitia Museum is easily accessed and worth a peek if you appreciate paintings by renowned Mexican artists. It's just across the street of the north side of Parque Sierra de Alicia, which is by the acqueduct, just an 8 - 10 minute walk from the Zacatecas Cathedral in Centro.

 It houses about 5 or 6 rooms, but an impressive variety of paintings from "great Zacatecan masters...,such as Julio Rueles, Francisco Goitia, José Kuri Brena, Pedro Coronel, Rafael Coronel, and Manuel Felguerez, who all had extensive international recognition..." (Travel By Mexico). 

The building itself was the governor's residence and the outside facade still commands respect. The marbled staircase in the foyer is breathtaking. It's the only place visitors are allowed to photograph once inside the building, unfortunately. 

The gardens could use some tlc, but I don't imagine many cities wasting the amount of water it would require to fully restore these gardens.  As it was - and in November even, when I visited - the area was still pretty and serene, with a green manicured lawn and several roses bushes. 
If you are an art lover, or are exploring by foot, check it out. I'm not particularly artsy, so I spent maybe an hour here. It cost only 30 pesos. 

Enjoy Zacatecas!

address.streetAddress: Enrique Estrada 102 Col. Sierra de Alica

357380960.name: what a great museum !
357380960.author: a TripAdvisor user
357380960.reviewBody: This museum had very good paintings by Francisco Goitia and other famous painters.  One of my favorite Goitia paintings was on display "El Ahorcado".  Unfortunately no photos are allowed inside, however i still recommend this museum if your in Zacatecas.

address.streetAddress: Enrique Estrada 102 Col. Sierra de Alica

323255417.name: Well worth a visit.
323255417.author: a TripAdvisor user
323255417.reviewBody: This lovely old mansion that has been converted into a museum is dedicated to Zacatecan artists with occasional exhibits by other Mexican artists. On two floors connected by a lovely sweeping staircase, the amazing work of Francisco Goitia will certainly catch your eye, as well as works by the brothers Coronel. Allow time to stroll through the lovely gardens as well.

address.streetAddress: Enrique Estrada 102 Col. Sierra de Alica

259827614.name: Eye-opening artistic vision of early 20th Century Mexico
259827614.author: a TripAdvisor user
259827614.reviewBody: I had never heard of Franciso Goitia and what a revelation I found in this museum. The permanent collection here is excellent and I was very engaged by the temporary exhibit "anida" by Susanna Salinas - an exploration of the nest as nurturer, hindrance and probably more than this viewer is able to put into words. If Mexico\'s history and art is of interest to you, do not miss this. A gem indeed.

address.streetAddress: Enrique Estrada 102 Col. Sierra de Alica

120800154.name: Excellent Little Museum
120800154.author: a TripAdvisor user
120800154.reviewBody: I agree with the prior review. This is a wonderful little museum with very interesting art by a number of artists, not just Goitia. It is just slightly off the beaten   path at the outer edge of the historic district but worth the few minutes walk to get there.

address.streetAddress: Enrique Estrada 102 Col. Sierra de Alica

118022661.name: Contemporary art in a historic mansion
118022661.author: a TripAdvisor user
118022661.reviewBody: Francisco Goitia, an important Mexican artist whose life spanned the 19th and 20th centuries, had a tortured and mostly poverty-afflicted life, making it an odd bit of irony that his art  should now be housed in such a handsome ex-governor\'s mansion. But this turns out to  be a wonderful setting for his moving portraits and landscapes, for permanent collections of works by such other Zacatecan master artists as Julio Ruelas,  Jos\u00e9 Kuri Bre\u00f1a, Pedro Coronel, Manuel Felgu\u00e9rez and Rafael Coronel -- and for changing exhibits, concerts, and conferences. Not only is this an easy walk from the center, but you can catch a glimpse  of the city\'s erstwhile aqueduct system when crossing the street from here to view the beautiful Quinta Real hotel, built around a historic bullring.

address.streetAddress: Enrique Estrada 102 Col. Sierra de Alica

659705368.name: Superb wine,paired with exciting cuisine
659705368.author: a TripAdvisor user
659705368.reviewBody: We took a taxi to the Tierra Adentro winery with another couple from Zacatecas (23 K).After a great tour through the vines and cellar with chef and sommelier , Luciano,we headed to the restaurant , Albuquerque,for lunch, We were really impressed, The physical setting was lovely and relaxing.The service was impeccable. All of us had different appetizers which were fresh and interesting,Particularly good were the sopa de tortillas, the Caprese salad, tortellini a la putanesca, and salmon Chileano.All wines were from their own vineyard . I recommend the Merlot 2016 and the Rose 2017. It was lovely and tart. \nCan\u2019t wait to go again!

656441578.name: Impressive nativity collection!
656441578.author: a TripAdvisor user
656441578.reviewBody: If you are a Nativity collector, this is the place to visit. The collection has nativities from different states and artists.\nThey have some for sale that are unique made by local artists, it is worth the visit!

address.streetAddress: Calle Hidalgo frente a la Plaza de Armas

655183225.name: An unexpected gem
655183225.author: a TripAdvisor user
655183225.reviewBody: I went into the  Galeria de Nacimientos, across from the Cathedral plaza, expecting to find a variety of nacimientos for sale. There were some, but the wonderful surprise was a museum filled with hundreds of nacimientos from all over the world. They are made from a variety of materials----clay, cloth, onyx, ceramic, straw---and all reflect the native faces and dress of their country of origin. Most touching for me, however, was the love that was obvious in their making. \n

268115681.name: Excellent
268115681.author: a TripAdvisor user
268115681.reviewBody: The garden setting is absolutely stunning as is the art inside. I was very moved by the works displayed especially the revolutionary-themed works and the indigenous portraits. There is a rotating exhibit on the second floor which changes every three months. The total experience is incredible.

234222328.name: Excelente
234222328.author: a TripAdvisor user
234222328.reviewBody: There is excellence all around at this slightly out of the way museum, located in a really gorgeous mansion at the edge of the historic center. I loved the contrast of the rather harsh art with the delicacy of the effete architecture. Beautiful gardens were a bonus.

127383014.reviewBody: The collection is very rich. You will definitely enjoy it! The building is also a lovely place.
